Zero-knowledge proof
In cryptography, a zero-knowledge proof or zero-knowledge protocol is a method by which one party (the prover) can prove to another party (the verifier) that a given statement is true, while avoiding conveying to the verifier any information beyond the mere fact of the statement's truth. The intuition underlying zero-knowledge proofs is that it ...

TK | csjaybit
what is use of bootloader contract?
Vlad B | zkSync 10/03/2023 14:26
Bootloader is the program that starts with EraVM execution. Basically, it is the only program that EraVM executes, all transaction data are validated with Bootloader code so it is how we prove the batch.

BenRai

Vlad B | zkSync 10/03/2023 14:32
This is a good one. Firstly, we expect bugs to be found between different components. To understand system contracts or bootloader you need to understand VM, to understand L1 contracts you need to know what checks are done on L2 and what enforces it. That's why I (personally) think having three different pools will make a separation between components and will provide the same value as having three different contests where a complete picture of the system will be missed.

deadrosesxyz
@Trebien | C4 hey quick question, if valid H/M are found, is the base pool increased proportionally (h/m, qa, judge etc. all get increased) or only H/M pool is increased?
shealtielanz 10/03/2023 15:21
Normal if no H/M is found in a contest, the contest pool for H/Ms is shared amongst the wardens with a Grade a QA report, If no H/M is found the amount shared would be $330k but a situation where medium/s is found the contest pool would be increased to 700k approx to be shared amongst wardens who found such severity. I believe the point for doing this is to avoid sharing $1.1m to wardens if the are incapable of finding a medium or high severity issue in the codebase. (edited)

Vlad B | zkSync 10/04/2023 14:18
Mailbox is a part of the diamond proxy, so it is kind of one big contract where the queue is stored. Executor is also a part of the diamond proxy and manages the state transition. When state transition happens (commitBatches/proveBatches/executeBatches) L1 -> L2 transactions are taken from the queue.

AS 10/05/2023 13:01

AS
Can I think zkSync have a single L2 node where system contracts and bootloader are deployed? And L2 User workflow will start to call json rpc on this node which is one part of Ethereum chain?
Vlad B | zkSync 10/05/2023 13:04
So, you can think about zkSync as a separate blockchain with trustless bridge to Ethereum (in fact it is more than that, but for simplicity). zkSync have one centralized node at the moment where all transactions are executed. System contracts and bootloader are deployed on this specific blockchain and if user wants to make a transaction, yes, they should call zkSync RPC but it is separate instance RPC from Ethereum.

Vlad B | zkSync 10/05/2023 17:12
So, the validator is an entity that sequences transactions in the order (make a batch with transactions), processes them, and creates zk proof for their execution. The validator is not trusted in a term that the validator shouldn‚Äôt be able to steal the funds of the user. However, in the current form, it can provide or not refund for user transactions (this is trusted). (edited)

Noam Yakov 10/05/2023 21:58
What's the purpose of the VerifierParams struct and each of its fields?
Noam Yakov
What's the purpose of the VerifierParams struct and each of its fields?
Vlad B | zkSync 10/05/2023 22:37
So to verify zk circuits we need to generate verification keys. Verification keys are parameters for verifier so that verifier would accept proof only for specific zk circuit. VerifierParams are also parameters for verifier smart contract, but specific to our circuit architecture. In our architecture we do have recursive proofs. That means one zk proof can verify another one. The main circuit that do recursion and verify other proofs take as input hash of verification keys for other circuits - VerificationParams.

0xdeadc0de
Hello o/, FSM_input and FSM_output are just an other name for the struct VmLocalState ? (edited)
portport 10/06/2023 06:56
We sometimes want to run multiple copies of the same circuit back-to-back. It's important that the end state of one circuit (FSM_output for circuit 1) is the same as the start state of the next circuit (FSM_input for circuit 2). So yes the struct is the same for both, but it's nice to have the distinction between start and end states

ustas 10/06/2023 17:06
The hash of the code of the bootloader is stored on L1 and can only be changed as a part of a system upgrade. Note, that unlike system contracts, the bootloader‚Äôs code is not stored anywhere on L2. That‚Äôs why we may sometimes refer to the bootloader‚Äôs address as formal. It only exists for the sake of providing some value to this / msg.sender/etc. When someone calls the bootloader address (e.g. to pay fees) the EmptyContract‚Äôs code is actually invoked.

explanation from copilot: GitHub Copilot: The syntax you are referring to is called a code placeholder. It is used by the AI to insert dynamic content into code snippets. The placeholder is represented by a dollar sign followed by parentheses, like this: `$(placeholder)`. When you see a placeholder in the code, it means that the AI has replaced it with a value that it thinks is appropriate for the context. In the case of the code you provided, the placeholders are likely replaced with actual values by the AI before the code is executed.

ustas
What does the gas() instruction return in the Bootloader context? It must be the gas limit set by the operator for the entire batch execution, correct? Then I wonder about the purpose of the checkEnoughGas() function. If gas() ever runs out during some of the calls in a batch transaction, won't it simply revert automatically? https://github.com/code-423n4/2023-10-zksync/blob/ebec640786cf3cb791fa77a856ad9d2a554dad3f/code/system-contracts/bootloader/bootloader.yul#L1195 https://github.com/code-423n4/2023-10-zksync/blob/ebec640786cf3cb791fa77a856ad9d2a554dad3f/code/system-contracts/bootloader/bootloader.yul#L1779-L1790 (edited)
Vlad B | zkSync 10/10/2023 11:15
gas() in the context of Bootloader returns the same thing as in the context of other contracts. Bootloader is just a programs that runs on EraVM, so it has the same properties + some additional permissions and features due to the fact that this is the first program. First programs starts with 2^32 - 1 gas available for the execution.

carlos__alegre 10/11/2023 08:16
@Vlad B | zkSync why are the revert codes one or two letters?
0xladboy | Sparkware
Can I confirm this is not in scope?
Vlad B | zkSync 10/11/2023 10:15
Yes, it is out of scope
carlos__alegre
@Vlad B | zkSync why are the revert codes one or two letters?
Vlad B | zkSync 10/11/2023 10:19
Legacy and/or premature optimization. In previous version of zkSync (now it is called zkSync Lite) we used single implementation proxy (as UUPS or TransparentUpgradeableProxy) and had a problem with bytecode size. Basically implementation contract was too big to be deployed onchain. So, we change long revert messages to something shorter to save bytecode space.
1

I know this may sound complicated, but you can use this to help find whether the bot has a finding: https://illilli000.github.io/races/2023-07-lens/scorer2.html paste the rubric from the bottom of the raw bot report, then click [add] and provide your finding in this format: ### N-<n> <title>, e.g. ### N-01 Possible rounding issue, then click the score button, and it'll show you whether it knows about such a finding (the rubric column), based on a fuzzy match of the title you provided, checked against previous bot reports (edited)

0xladboy | Sparkware
can I sayÔºö commit batch in l1 contains a few block from l2Ôºü
Vlad B | zkSync 10/13/2023 09:32
That's correct
0xladboy | Sparkware
so the bootloader will also be a smart contract that is deployedÔºü
Vlad B | zkSync 10/13/2023 09:34
It is the first program that EraVM executed (and the only one program). You can think about it as for Operation System for the computer, it manages what transaction can be executed, what to check and how and much to take the fee. But it is not deployed contract, it is the convention that bootloader is executed by EraVM as the only program. On the L1, we do check that proof corresponds to the bootloader execution with the exact bootlaoder hash.
zhaojie
Can the user call the functions in the bootloader contract(0x8001), I use the test node can be called. @Vlad B | zkSync
Vlad B | zkSync 10/13/2023 09:35
No, while bootloader started the execution on EraVM and even has some formal address (0x8001) any call to bootloader in the call frame will execute EmptyContract.sol

Mahi_Vasisth
Why you use _claimining variable in _verifyDepositLimit() of L1ERC20Bridge.sol . Can u please tell me the perspective of using this (edited)
adeolu 10/14/2023 07:05
_verifyDepositLimit() is used in two ways. when adding to total user deposit (in deposit()) and when subtracting from it (via claimFailedDeposit()). _claiming is true for claimFailedDeposit() and false for the other.

hash
Hey, In the following issue https://code4rena.com/reports/2023-03-zksync#h-01-the-call-to-msgvaluesimulator-with-non-zero-msgvalue-will-call-to-sender-itself-which-will-bypass-the-onlyself-check , are the values in r3,r4 and r5 on reentrancy coming due to WILL mess up the registers and WILL use r1-r4 for our standard ABI convention and r5 for the extra who_to_mimic argument or due to the usage of registers in performing operations? And what is meant by the return value being WILL mess up the registers and WILL use r1-r4 for our standard ABI convention and r5 for the extra who_to_mimic argument for the mimic_call_byref opcode?
Vlad B | zkSync 10/21/2023 11:39
So, a contract can pass non-zero register to the call in case systemCall flag is set to true. We use this non-standard ABI for efficiency and to distinguish EVM ABI that users can use. MsgValueSimulator is using register for getting (value, to, isSystemCall) parameters to the call that is need to be mimic. In case to == msgValueSimulator address and isSystemCall is set to true then MsgValueSimulator reenter itself with registers that caller didn't set in purpose (some not cleaned register that MsgValueSimulator used in the execution).
due to WILL mess up the registers and WILL use r1-r4 for our standard ABI convention and r5 for the extra who_to_mimic argument or due to the usage of registers in performing operations?
They are coming due to usage of isSystemCall and they are messy due to not specific setting of such register, but rather using register that is left from the execution.
And what is meant by the return value being WILL mess up the registers and WILL use r1-r4 for our standard ABI convention and r5 for the extra who_to_mimic argument for the mimic_call_byref opcode?
That's being said, register in the frame will be passed to the next frame if isSystemCall flag is set.
Vlad B | zkSync 10/21/2023 11:48
Please ping me in DM if I forgot to answer to someone.

due to WILL mess up the registers and WILL use r1-r4 for our standard ABI convention and r5 for the extra who_to_mimic argument or due to the usage of registers in performing operations?

That's being said, register in the frame will be passed to the next frame if isSystemCall flag is set.

unforgiven 11/02/2023 18:44
backstage is very unfair feature of the Code4rena! warden without backstage access are in dark until the final result! and also: 1. they can't escalate their issues (losing valid issues because of reports lack some facts) 2. other wardens can escalate and downgrade their issues!! 3. they can only see the contest result (including their issues) only after final report which is 2-4 month later most of the time. 4. wardens with backstage access can add POC, extra proof and evidence to their submission in scalation phase, it means they have 1 month more than other wardens(without access) to participate in contest. there was a feature request that each warden sees his/her own issues and escalate them before final result, but even after more than one year, this feature is not implemented. the most sad part is because of no escalation, this happens:
  • warden solo HIGH and MEDIUM most likely is going to be set as invalid, because of the issue's nature, it is solo!! no one knows about it and it's hard to imagine that bug. I suggest to give all wardens ability to escalate their reports ASAP.
 (edited)

dontonka 02/13/2024 05:29
Whatever anyone says to you, access to backstage and being able to fight in Post-QA is a big deal. In my last contest, I had an issue which was qualified as QA by the lookout, with about 6 duplicates, judge agreed with the lookout, then I demonstrated in PostQA why this was a High, sponsor confirmed, then judge increased to Medium only somehow. Post QA concluded. I ping again the judge in the PostQA discussion trying to understand why this was not classified as a High, then after few days the judge agreed to increase as High. So my issue started as a QA with 6 full duplicates and with my input in PostQA concluded as a High with only 3 duplicates (mine primary, the 2 other partial-25). I don't think this is an exceptional case and happen from time to time.
